title: R43984
content: Songwriters and recording artists are entitled to payment for reproductions and performances of their music. However, they do not have complete control over their music, as demonstrated by Taylor Swift's music being available on Spotify through a cover version despite her withdrawal. Taylor Swift can withdraw her own recorded music from Spotify as a singer who owns the rights to her sound recordings. However, as a songwriter who owns the rights to her musical works, she cannot control how the music service uses other recorded versions of her songs. The payment she receives for her music depends on market forces, contracts, and federal laws. Congress wrote laws governing copyright and competition policy at a time when music was primarily accessed through radio and physical media. In the 1990s, laws were updated to address music distribution on the internet, balancing copyright protection and combating unauthorized use. The music industry has seen a shift in copyright laws as digital services have evolved. Music consumption has changed with the rise of streaming services, blurring traditional lines of exploitation. Recording industry revenues peaked at $21.3 billion in 1999. In 1999, recording industry revenues peaked at $21.3 billion. The introduction of Napster in the same year revolutionized file-sharing. Apple's iTunes Music Store launched in 2003, offering legal song purchases online. By 2012, digital downloads surpassed physical media sales, with Apple dominating the market. However, digital download sales started declining after 2012 due to the rise of streaming services. The rise of streaming services like Spotify led to a decline in digital download sales, prompting Apple to launch Apple Music in 2015. Subscription music services now account for a significant portion of total U.S. recording industry retail spending, increasing from 9% in 2011 to 67% in 2017 according to the RIAA. Consumer spending on music saw a significant shift from declining revenues to flat growth between 2014 and 2015, followed by a 10% increase between 2015 and 2016, and a 14% increase between 2016 and 2017. Despite these changes, annual spending on music by U.S. consumers remains nearly two-thirds below its 1999 peak, impacting how performers and music creators are compensated under copyright law. Owners of musical works have legal rights and typically license them to third parties. These rights include the right to reproduce and distribute the work, known as a "mechanical right." The term "mechanical right" dates back to the 1909 Copyright Act, where music publishers issued licenses for the reproduction of musical compositions. Despite changes in technology, such as vinyl records and digital copies, the term has remained to refer to reproduction and distribution rights for music. The Copyright Act provides federal protection for sound recordings fixed after February 15, 1972. Owners of musical works and sound recordings have the right to perform works publicly, but for sound recordings, this right only applies to digital audio transmissions. Some music services have agreements to pay royalties for pre-1972 recordings. Sound recording public performance rights under federal copyright laws are granted only to recordings fixed after February 15, 1972, for digital audio transmissions. Examples include webcasting, digital subscription services, and music streaming services like Pandora and Spotify. Consumers of compact discs purchase rights to listen to songs as often as they wish. Retail outlets selling digital or physical sound recordings pay distribution subsidiaries of major record labels. Radio listeners have less control over song playback compared to purchasing the song. Broadcast radio stations are not required to pay public performance royalties to record labels and artists under the Copyright Act. The Copyright Act does not require broadcast radio stations to pay public performance royalties to record labels and artists, but they must pay royalties to music publishers and songwriters for notes and lyrics. Congress determined in 1995 that the promotional value of radio airplay outweighs revenue lost by record labels and artists. Digital services must pay both record labels and music publishers for public performance rights. Interactive music streaming services allow users to choose songs they want to hear, making temporary copies known as "ephemeral recordings." These services also offer on-demand listening experiences similar to playing a CD or listening to a radio broadcast, where digital files are downloaded to consumers' devices for multiple listeners to select songs. These digital reproductions are called "conditional downloads." The music industry comprises three categories: songwriters and music publishers, recording artists and record labels, and music licensees. These entities receive royalties for reproducing and distributing musical works and sound recordings. Songwriters work with music publishers to promote songs and license intellectual property. Publishers may pay advances to songwriters in exchange for a portion of the copyright in their compositions. The publisher's role is to monitor, promote, and generate revenue from music in various formats requiring mechanical licensing rights. They often contract with performing rights organizations to collect payment for public performances. Songwriters and publishers share royalty income with subpublishers and coauthors. Music publishers in the music industry have standardized contract terms with a 50-50 income division between publisher and songwriter. Major publishers like Sony/ATV, Universal Music, and Warner Music account for over half of U.S. music publishing revenue. Independent publishing companies handle the creative aspects of songwriting management. Independent publishers manage their own music catalogs and are not affiliated with major publishers. Some songwriters control their own publishing rights and may hire individuals to administer their royalties. Record labels are responsible for finding musical talent. Record labels, including the three major ones, are responsible for discovering talent, recording music, and promoting artists. They also distribute physical and electronic copies of sound recordings through large networks. The distribution role of record labels is evolving due to the decline in physical music consumption. Record labels handle various functions related to selling digital copies of songs, including adding data for royalty identification, negotiating with streaming services, and monitoring sales. Recording artists can either contract with a label or distribute their own recordings. Contracts often involve transferring copyrights to the label for specific periods and regions in exchange for services. Record labels sign recording artists to contracts for defined periods and regions, providing financial support and guidance in exchange for a share of royalties. Major record labels like Sony, Universal, and Warner dominate the industry's revenue. The music industry is dominated by major record labels like Sony, Universal, and Warner. Many smaller record labels rely on these majors for distribution. For example, Taylor Swift is signed to Big Machine Records, which has a distribution agreement with Universal Music Group. Chance the Rapper, a recording artist, retains his copyrights and distributes his music independently. He gives away his music for free, earns from tours and merchandise sales. Apple Music paid him $500,000 for exclusive streaming rights to his album, Coloring Book. The album made history by ranking among the top 10 U.S. albums in a week on Billboard. The 1909 Copyright Act recognized the copyright owner's exclusive right to make mechanical reproductions of music. A mechanical license allows for audio-only reproduction of music on mechanical devices like player pianos, phonograph records, and CDs. Concerns arose during the 1909 Copyright Act about a player-piano manufacturer, Aeolian Company, potentially creating a monopoly by acquiring exclusive rights from music publishers. In response to concerns about a potential monopoly by Aeolian Company, Congress established the first compulsory license in U.S. copyright law. This allows music publishers to withhold the right to reproduce a musical work, but once a sound recording is distributed to the public, others can use it upon payment of a royalty. For example, when Ryan Adams covered Taylor Swift's album 1989 in 2015, he did not need her permission but paid a specified rate. The Copyright Alternative in Small-Claims Enforcement (CASE) Act of 2017, H.R. 3945, introduced by Representative Hakeem Jeffries, aims to establish a Copyright Claims Board for copyright owners to address infringement cases outside of U.S. district courts. The board, housed within the Copyright Office, would handle civil copyright cases with damages capped at $30,000. The Accessibility for Curators, Creators, Educators, Scholars, and Society (ACCESS) to Recordings Act, S. 2933, introduced by Senator Ron Wyden in May 2018, aims to provide federal copyright protection for pre-1972 sound recordings. This bill would allow rights holders to receive payments from digital services for public performances of their works and preempt state copyright protection. Owners of pre-1972 sound recording copyrights would need to give timely notice during a three-year window to be eligible for statutory damages or attorney's fees for infringement. Pre-1972 sound recording copyright owners must provide timely notice of federal copyright registration and infringement to the alleged infringer. If infringement has ceased when action is taken, owners cannot receive statutory damages or attorney's fees. Sound recordings made before February 15, 1972, enter the public domain 95 years after release or 120 years after recording. Works recorded between 1923 and 1930 are protected until December 31, 2025. Works recorded between 1923 and 1930 are protected until December 31, 2025, if the copyright owner engages in normal commercial exploitation, complies with regulations, and notifies the Register of Copyrights; otherwise, the recordings enter the public domain.
